maml:description.maml:para: Export a timer object to an XML file.
Use this command to export timer objects to a file. You might want to do this if the "timer" is still running and you will use it in a later PowerShell session.
The default behavior is to export all timer variables or you can select specific ones by name.

maml:Description.maml:para: The name of a timer to export. The default is to export all timers.
The file name for the XML file to create.
The name of a timer to export. The default is to export all timers.
The file name for the XML file to create.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Export all timers to the specified file.

maml:description.maml:para: Get a history runtime object.
Use this command to see how long something took to run in PowerShell.

maml:Description.maml:para: Enter a history item ID. The default is the last command executed.
Include history detail in the result.
Pass a history object to this command.
Include history detail in the result.
Enter a history item ID. The default is the last command executed.
Pass a history object to this command.
Include history detail in the result.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 4 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
Get-History -count 5 | Get-HistoryRuntime -detail
ID RunTime Status Command -- ------- ------ ------- 105 00:01:10.9210044 Completed get-service -comp chi-dc01,chi-dc02,chi-core01... 106 00:00:00.4872217 Completed get-service -comp chi-dc01,chi-dc02,chi-p50 | ... 107 00:00:03.2367861 Completed get-ciminstance -comp chi-dc01,chi-p50,chi-dc0... 108 00:00:00.3980214 Completed ps 109 00:00:00.1019850 Completed get-ciminstance -comp chi-dc01,chi-p50,chi-dc0...

maml:description.maml:para: Get the current status of a simple timer.
Use this command to get the current status of a timer created with Start-MyTimer. It will display a current elapsed time but will not stop the timer.

maml:Description.maml:para: The name for your timer.
Get all timers.
The name for your timer.
Get all timers.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Get the current status of a timer called T2.

maml:description.maml:para: Import a timer variable from an XML file.
If you exported a timer variable with Export-MyTimer you can use this command to import it into your current session. Any existing variables with the same name will be overwritten.

maml:Description.maml:para: The file name for the XML file.
The file name for the XML file.

maml:description.maml:para: Remove a myTimer object.
MyTimer objects remain even after they have been stopped. Used this command to remove the timer object. It doesn't matter if the timer is running or not.

maml:Description.maml:para: The name of your timer object.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
The name of your timer object.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

maml:description.maml:para: Modify a MyTimer object.
Use this command to modify an existing timer.

maml:Description.maml:para: Enter the name of the object to modify.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Enter a new description for the timer object.
Enter a new name for the timer object.
Write the updated object to the pipeline.
Update the start time for your timer object.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Enter a new description for the timer object.
Enter the name of the object to modify.
Enter a new name for the timer object.
Write the updated object to the pipeline.
Update the start time for your timer object.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Modify the T1 timer with a new description

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> get-mytimer foo | set-mytimer -newName Work1 -Start "7/17/18 9:00AM"

dev:remarks.maml:para: Get the timer called foo and give it a new name and start time.

maml:description.maml:para: Start a simple timer.

This command starts a simple timer. You start it, which captures the current date and time, and stores the result in a global variable. You have the option of naming your timer which will allow you to have multiple timers running at the same time. Timer names must be unique. You can also add a brief description.

maml:Description.maml:para: The name for your timer. You can create multiple timers at the same time. See examples.
Enter an optional description for this timer.
The name for your timer. You can create multiple timers at the same time. See examples.
Enter an optional description for this timer.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Start the timer with the default name of MyTimer.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> Start-MyTimer Timer2
Name : timer2 Start : 7/17/2018 11:14:23 AM Duration : 00:00:00 Running : True Description :

dev:remarks.maml:para: Create a second timer called Timer2 and pass the object to the pipeline.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 3 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> start-mytimer Z -Description "work stuff"
Name : Z Start : 7/17/2018 11:18:02 AM Duration : 00:00:00 Running : True Description : work stuff

dev:remarks.maml:para: Create a new timer with a description.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 4 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> start-mytimer alpha,bravo,charlie
Name : alpha Start : 7/17/2018 11:23:49 AM Duration : 00:00:00 Running : True Description :
Name : bravo Start : 7/17/2018 11:23:49 AM Duration : 00:00:00 Running : True Description :
Name : charlie Start : 7/17/2018 11:23:49 AM Duration : 00:00:00 Running : True Description :

maml:description.maml:para: Start a graphical countdown display.

This command will display countdown progress bar using Write-Progress. You can set the timer for a specific time or number of minutes. The countdown includes humorous items to indicate time passing. These items are drawn from an included list but you can specify a path to custom items.
Start-PSCountdown is inspired from code originally published at: https://github.com/Windos/powershell-depot/blob/master/livecoding.tv/StreamCountdown/StreamCountdown.psm1

This command should work in Windows PowerShell and PowerShell Core, although not in VS Code. The ProgressStyle parameter is dynamic and only appears if you are running the command in a Windows console.

maml:Description.maml:para: Enter the number of minutes to countdown (1-60). The default is 5.
Enter a primary message to display in the parent window.
Use this parameter to clear the screen prior to starting the countdown.
The path to a text list of pseudo-tasks
Select a progress bar style. This only applies when using the Windows PowerShell console or ISE.
Default - use the current value of $host.PrivateData.ProgressBarBackgroundColor
Transparent - set the progress bar background color to the same as the console
Random - randomly cycle through a list of console colors
Enter the text for the progress bar title.
Enter a datetime value as the countdown target.
Enter a primary message to display in the parent window.
Use this parameter to clear the screen prior to starting the countdown.
The path to a text list of pseudo-tasks
Select a progress bar style. This only applies when using the Windows PowerShell console or ISE.
Default - use the current value of $host.PrivateData.ProgressBarBackgroundColor
Transparent - set the progress bar background color to the same as the console
Random - randomly cycle through a list of console colors
Enter the text for the progress bar title.
Use this parameter to clear the screen prior to starting the countdown.
Enter a primary message to display in the parent window.
Enter the number of minutes to countdown (1-60). The default is 5.
The path to a text list of pseudo-tasks
Select a progress bar style. This only applies when using the Windows PowerShell console or ISE.
Default - use the current value of $host.PrivateData.ProgressBarBackgroundColor
Transparent - set the progress bar background color to the same as the console
Random - randomly cycle through a list of console colors
Enter a datetime value as the countdown target.
Enter the text for the progress bar title.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Start a countdown display set to expire in 5 minutes.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Start-PSCountdown -time 9:00AM -title "Welcome Back" -message "Review your class notes and have questions ready" -clearhost -progressStyle random

dev:remarks.maml:para: Start a countdown timer to 9:00AM. The screen will be cleared and the progress bar color will cycle through a random set of colors.

maml:description.maml:para: Initiates a countdown before running a command.

This is a variation on the Start-Countdown script from Josh Atwell (http://www.vtesseract.com/post/21414227113/start-countdown-function-a-visual-for-start-sleep). It can be used instead of Start-Sleep and provides a visual countdown progress during "sleep" times. At the end of the countdown, your command will execute. Press the ESC key any time during the countdown to abort.
USING START-COUNTDOWN IN THE POWERSHELL ISE

Results will vary slightly in the PowerShell ISE. If you use this in the ISE, it is recommended to use -Clear. You also cannot use the ESC key to abort the script if using the console. You'll need to press Ctrl+C. If using the progress bar, there is a Stop button in the ISE. If you abort in the ISE, you won't get the warning message.

maml:Description.maml:para: The number of seconds to countdown.
A PowerShell scriptblock to execute at the end of the countdown.
Use a progress bar instead of the console.
The activity title, normally displayed at the top of the progress bar.
Clear the screen. Other wise, the countdown will use the current location.
The message to be displayed at the end of the countdown before any scriptblock is executed.
The number of seconds to countdown.
A PowerShell scriptblock to execute at the end of the countdown.
Use a progress bar instead of the console.
The activity title, normally displayed at the top of the progress bar.
Clear the screen. Other wise, the countdown will use the current location.
The message to be displayed at the end of the countdown before any scriptblock is executed.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This method will clear the screen and display descending seconds.
This method will display a progress bar on screen. At the end of the countdown the scriptblock will execute.

maml:description.maml:para: Stop your simple timer.
This command will stop any timer created with Start-MyTimer. When executed it which will calculate a timespan and remove the timer variable. You can also opt to get the timespan as a string.

maml:Description.maml:para: The name for your timer.
Prompt for confirmation before stopping the timer and removing the variable.
Using this parameter will display what the final value would be but not actually stop it.
By default, the command does not write an object to the pipeline. Use -Passthru to force an object through.
Prompt for confirmation before stopping the timer and removing the variable.
The name for your timer.
Using this parameter will display what the final value would be but not actually stop it.
By default, the command does not write an object to the pipeline. Use -Passthru to force an object through.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> Stop-MyTimer Timer2 -passthru
Name Start Duration Running Description ---- ----- -------- ------- ----------- t2 10/25/2018 9:37:18 AM 00:20:19.0345972 False

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> $report = import-csv s:\computers.csv | foreach -begin { Start-MyTimer T1; Write-Host "Starting the process" -foreground cyan } -process { Get-CimInstance win32_logicaldisk -computer $_.computername} -end { Write-Host "Finished! $((Stop-MyTimer T1 -passthru).duration)" -foreground cyan}
Starting the process Finished! 00:00:29.1625955

dev:remarks.maml:para: Import a list of computers and get disk information for each one. The command uses a timer to measure how long the process took.
